channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DERBY-3958] ImportExportProcedures imports ./testData/ImportExport/position_info.del using US-ASCII but the file contains non-ascii characters
item.description:
Either the file should be changed to have only ascii characters or switched to import with whatever encoding the file is intended to have. Here are the characters that don't fall within the 1-127 range.

133 at line 241
146 at line 247
146 at line 275
146 at line 379
146 at line 676
149 at line 887
149 at line 888
149 at line 889

I used this small program to analyze the file:
import java.io.*;

public class CheckFileForGarbage {

public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception{
if (args.length != 1)

{ System.out.println("usage CheckFileForGarbage <filename>"); System.exit(-1); }

File f = new File(args[0]);
FileInputStream fos = new FileInputStream(f);
int i;
int line = 0;
do

{ i = fos.read(); if ( i == '\n') line++; if (i == 0 || i > 128) System.out.println( i + " at line " + line ); }

while (i != -1);

}

}

I am inclined to just replace these with question marks and resubmit the file.
item.summary: ImportExportProcedures imports ./testData/ImportExport/position_info.del using US-ASCII but the file contains non-ascii characters

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Attached is a patch for this issue that just replaces the non-ascii characters in position_info.del with '?'. I'll check this in tomorrow if nobody has comments.

The file is encoded with CP1252. Instead of replacing the non-ascii characters with question marks, we could replace them with their ascii-equivalents so that the data looks more meaningful. Only these eight non-ascii characters are used:

133 - ... (ellipsis)
145 - ' (opening single quote, ordinary single quote is probably fine to use)
146 - ' (closing single quote, ordinary single quote is probably fine to use)
147 - " (actually opening double quote)
148 - " (actually closing double quote)
149 - * (bullet)
150 - - (dash)
160 - space (non-breaking space, actually, but ordinary space should be fine)
Here is the updated patch with the substitutions Knut recommended. For opening and closing double quotes, I just replaced two single quotes. Replacing with a double quote caused problems on import.
Sounds good to me. I verified that the test runs cleanly with the patch applied. +1 to commit.
